title: 111_hr6039
content:
The Act titled "Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area Act of 2010" defines key terms such as Heritage Area, local coordinating entity, management plan, map, Secretary, and State. The Act establishes the Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area. The Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area is established in the State, encompassing approximately 1,444 square miles of land in 15 counties in central and southeastern Wisconsin. It includes contributing sites, buildings, and districts recommended for inclusion in the Heritage Area by the management plan. The Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area covers 1,444 square miles in 15 counties in central and southeastern Wisconsin. The boundaries can be revised if proposed in the management plan, depicted on the map, and approved by the Secretary. The map is available for public inspection at the National Park Service and the local coordinating entity, which is the Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway nonprofit organization. The administration of the Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area is outlined in Section 4. The administration of the Fox-Wisconsin Heritage Parkway National Heritage Area allows the Secretary to use funds for grants, cooperative agreements, hiring staff, obtaining funds or services, and entering into contracts. The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area has duties including preparing and submitting a management plan, assisting local organizations with projects, and serving as a catalyst for activities that further the goals of the Heritage Area. The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area has duties such as establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational opportunities, increasing public awareness, protecting historic sites, ensuring clear signage, and promoting partnerships. The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area has duties such as establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational opportunities, increasing public awareness, protecting historic sites, ensuring clear signage, and promoting partnerships. Governments, organizations, and individuals further the Heritage Area; consider diverse interests in the preparation and implementation of the management plan; conduct public meetings semiannually; submit annual reports to the Secretary for audit. The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area must provide records for audit, promote economic viability, and cannot use federal funds to acquire real property. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The local coordinating entity must submit a proposed management plan for the Heritage Area to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of various resources, consider State and local plans, and include an inventory of resources, policies for conservation and development, and actions by governments. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area must include actions agreed upon by governments, private organizations, and individuals to protect natural, cultural, historic, scenic, educational, and recreational resources. It should also outline ongoing collaboration for resource protection, restoration, and construction, along with specific commitments for implementation within the first 5 years. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area should include actions to protect resources, funding sources, coordination of programs, interpretive plan, and resource management policies. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area must include actions to protect natural, cultural, historic, scenic, educational, and recreational resources. If the plan is not submitted within 3 years, the local coordinating entity will lose funding until the Secretary approves a plan within 180 days. The Secretary will consider if the entity is representative when approving the plan. The local coordinating entity's representation of diverse interests, public involvement in the management plan preparation, and the effectiveness of resource protection strategies are key factors considered for approval. If the Secretary disapproves the management plan, they must advise the local coordinating entity of reasons for disapproval, make recommendations for revisions, and approve or disapprove any proposed revision within 180 days. The Secretary also approves or disapproves substantial changes to the management plan through amendments. The local coordinating entity must obtain approval from the Secretary before using Federal funds for any amendments to the management plan authorized by this Act. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In general, this Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and local coordinating entity. The Act does not change laws authorizing Federal land management or limit the discretion of Federal land managers within the Heritage Area. The Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws or modify any authorized use of Federal land under their jurisdiction. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act ensures that property owners' rights are not infringed upon within the Heritage Area, including the right to refuse participation in any activities. It does not mandate public access to private property or modify existing land use regulations. Additionally, it does not transfer any regulatory authority to the local coordinating entity. The local coordinating entity is authorized to manage water and wildlife within the Heritage Area, but cannot infringe on property owners' rights or create liability for injuries on private property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION; REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the progress of the local coordinating entity, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary will review the management structure, partnership relationships, and funding of the Heritage Area to identify critical components for sustainability. A report will be prepared with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress, including recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service and ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding. SEC. 9. FUNDING.

Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with $1,000,000 limit per year. Funds remain available until expended. Cost-sharing requirement of not more than 50% Federal share for activities. Non-Federal share can be in-kind contributions.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY.

Secretary's assistance authority under the Act ends 15 years after enactment.
